text:
Hello, my name is Emma, and I have a very
special video for you today. Today, we are

going to play a game with my sister Audra,
but before we play our game, I wanted to teach

you something. I'm going to teach you about
the word "will". We use "will" a lot in English.

We use "will" when we want to make a prediction
about something. So, what's a predication?

Well, a prediction is when we talk about what
we think is going to happen in the future.

So, for example, what will happen in 2050?
That's an example of a question with a prediction

in it. So, today, we're going to play a game
with this word "will".

Let me tell you now how we use "will" in a
sentence. We always have the word "will" followed

by a verb, and the verb is in the base form,
okay? So, I'll give you an example. I have

here a very famous sentence: I will be back,
or I'll be back, if you've ever seen Terminator,

this is an example of a sentence with the
word "will". Notice we have the subject "I",

we have our word "will", which is our prediction
word or our word that tells us it's about

the future, and we have our verb "to be".
I will be back. So, this is an example of

how we use "will" in a sentence. Now, one
problem a lot of English language learners

have is with these things called contractions.
So, a contraction is when we take two words

and we make them into one word, and we lose
a letter and add an apostrophe. So, "I will",

in the contraction form becomes "I'll". So,
this is what, for example, Arnold Schwarzenegger

says: "I'll be back". He says that instead
of "I will be back", but they mean the same
thing.

So, we also have "you will" can become "you'll",
"he will" becomes "he'll", "she will" becomes

"she'll", "it will" becomes, can you guess,
"it'll", "we will" can become "we'll", so

"we'll be back", and "they will" becomes "they'll".
So, we will be using these when we talk about

the future with my sister Audra. There's one
other thing I wanted to teach you before we

get to our game, and that is the negative
form of "will". So, when we want to say something

is not going to happen in the future, we can
say "It will not happen.", or we can use the

contraction, which is "won't". So, for example,
"I won't be back.". He won't be back. She

won't be back. It won't be back. Okay? So,
"won't" is the negative form of "will", and

again, "won't" is followed by a verb. Alright,
so, now the grammar is finished. Now, it is
time to play our fun game with my sister Audra.

So, this is my sister Audra. You may have
seen her in a video before.

- Audra, do you remember this game from when
we were children?

-
- I do; it was one of my favorites. I loved

it.
-

- So, this game, MASH, is actually a common
game kids in Canada play. I'm going to explain

the rules to Audra and to you and then we
will get to practice our verbs for today,

will and won't. Okay, so we have here a box,
and we have some letters at the top of this

box. M stands for mansion. A mansion is a
very big house that rich people live in. Think

about the White House, that's an example of
a mansion. A stands for apartment. S can stand

for shack. A shack is a really poor house
that is falling apart - that is, you know,

a terrible house. Nobody wants to live in
a shack. And H stands for house, okay? So,

this game is a game of prediction. We are
going to predict Audra's future. We're going

to find out, is Audra going to live in a mansion,
an apartment, a shack, or a house. Audra,

what are you hoping for?

- Fingers crossed, mansion. I think that's
a - a goal would be mansion.

is "She will". So, she'll live in a mansion.
She'll be married to Ryan Gosling. She'll
